urn:contentItem:5XWB-B931-JBCN-40WG-00000-00What’s legal (or illegal) in your state in 2020?2019-12-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:28ZLexisNexisNATIONWhat’s legal (or illegal) in your state in 2020?Vanessa Swales

California lawmakers made their fashion ruling: Crocodile handbags were out. Alligator boots, too. But for Louisiana, the nation's top producer of all things made from alligator skin, those were fighting words.

The state's attorney general filed a federal lawsuit this month to stop California's ban on alligator and crocodile products from taking effect in 2020. Last week, a federal judge agreed to temporarily block the new law, meaning Louisiana and California are headed for a showdown in court.

Every year on Jan. 1, hundreds of new state and federal laws take effect across the country. Many are mundane, but some can be contentious — and not just in the world of fashion.

As 2020 arrives Wednesday, Arkansas will ban state-funded human cloning, while Illinois will legalize marijuana. Texas will try to save lives in school shootings, but not by taking action on guns. Here's a look at changes coming across the country.

A new Texas law will require local school districts to stock wound kits on their campuses, equipped with tourniquets, chest seals, compression bandages, bleeding-control bandages, emergency blankets, latex-free gloves, markers and scissors.

Arkansas lawmakers voted to prohibit state funding of human cloning or destructive embryo research, stating that the "prospect of creating new human life solely to be exploited or destroyed has been condemned on moral grounds as displaying a profound disrespect for a human life."

Arizona, Maryland and Missouri prohibit the use of state funds to pay for reproductive cloning, while North Dakota, South Dakota and Oklahoma are the only states to ban all forms of human cloning.

California, home of some of the country's big tech giants, such as Google, Facebook and Yahoo, is rolling out a landmark digital privacy law that will regulate data collection from consumers.

Consumers will be able to request access to information that tech companies have collected about them and ask that the data be deleted. California is the first place to implement such a law in the United States.

Illinois will become the 11th state in the country, and the first in the Midwest, to legalize recreational marijuana sales and use.

New York will become the latest state to eliminate cash bail for misdemeanors and nonviolent felonies, which could see more than 40% of inmates released from pretrial detention, experts say.

Vanessa Swales is a New York Times writer.

urn:contentItem:5CH1-K3H1-JD6R-T01H-00000-00What SMEs can learn from State of Origin2014-06-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:28ZLexisNexisWhat SMEs can learn from State of OriginSmartCompany

So 'my' team, the NSW Blues, won the game on Wednesday night - the series decider - and since then my fellow New South Welsh-persons have been loud on all social media channels about it.

The last time NSW took the series from Queensland was so long ago (2006), Facebook wasn't yet available outside the US and Twitter didn't even exist. It was a year later that Apple shipped the first iPhone. #mindfck.

While the QLD Cane Toads and the NSW Cockroaches were smashing into each other with gusto and fans of both teams roared encouragement for 'their' team, I was in Melbourne, where nobody cares.

At the Uber Melbourne party a lot of Uber's customers wanted to talk about authorities in Australia and elsewhere issuing fines to UberX drivers, on the grounds they're unlicensed by the government bodies that license taxi drivers in those locales.

Like footy supporters passionately defending 'their' team, many of the Uber customers at the party were vocal about how unfair these bureaucrats were being. It wasn't just a government department battling a corporation, it was 'us' (Uber-plus-customers) versus 'them' (stoopid taxi licensing bureaucrats and evil, doomed taxi industry magnates). They sounded less like customers and more like Uber supporters, like this was a football match between Uber and the government regulator.

Interesting. And potentially valuable.

How do you create the conditions necessary to convert dispassionate, price-comparing, review-reading customers to passionate supporters? Supporters who'll defend your brand against all threats, real and perceived? What a powerful force for customer growth and retention. My guess is the same narratives that define a sporting allegiance also work for startup brands.

Be different, from a long way off

It helps if you're obviously externally different to your competitors, so much so that your customers can be separated from your competitor's customers at a distance.

If your customers can identify those not-like-them from a distance, they (like sports team supporters) can tell themselves apart from the 'enemy' in time to ensure they can maintain some separation. If you get too close to the enemy, you begin to realise how much you actually have in common, so prejudices are more easily maintained if you're keeping your distance.

If you're marketing one brand of smartphone against another, nobody can tell whether you're an Android fan or an iOS fan until you pull your smartphone out of your pocket. That's an issue.

Unless, of course, you're an Apple supporter wearing those easily-identifiable white Apple earbuds that have remained essentially the same through many generations of both earbud and in-ear product lines. The latest earbuds shipping with an iPhone 5s are easily identifiable as the progeny of the first earbuds that shipped with the very first iPod. Even when Apple introduced a colour range for iPods and then iPhones, the earbuds remained available only in one colour. Accidental? I think not.

Uber customers are potentially very different. When everyone else at the bar is glancing around wondering how hard it's going to be to hail a cab, and where they should start walking to, the Uber customer is still relaxed and casual at the bar - the iPhone app and push notification will let them know when the Uber car is approaching and they can waft out the door and straight in the town car.

Same at the destination - a taxi pulls over in a no-standing zone for what seems customer is futzing around with cash or credit card transactions. An Uber customer wafts out the door of their town car apparently without paying at all, safe in the knowledge the Uber platform will bill them a fair price when it notices customer and car have parted ways.

Uniform your supporters

Fierce though their allegiances are (and even though Apple includes an Apple sticker with every product it sells) you don't see a lot of branding on customers or their cars in the technology industry.

You can be pretty certain most people wearing a tech brand either work for the company behind the brand or have just attended an event where the branded gear was handed out.

I think that's partly because in tech the product itself is often all the branding you need - any noob can tell the difference between an Apple MacBook and a Dell CrapBook.

But I think it's also because in tech we're pretty sure we'd be helping a massively profitable corporation become more massively profitable by wearing its branded tees. Football teams are amongst the most successful corporations in the world though, so why don't fans of Manchester United feel like they're being exploited for corporate profit?

I think it's because the central narrative of, say, Google is "two smart nerdy guys get lucky with their first business out of school and are billionaires in a few years" whereas the central narrative of all successful sporting teams is, "This is a constant battle, we're on a razor's edge. We train ourselves to exhaustion, we devote our lives to the game, we give everything we have to every game we play, and if we don't we will be defeated."

That observation is supported by the higher frequency of supporter uniforms amongst underdog, challenger tech brands. The little team at Aussie startup Bugcrowd (disclosure: I'm an investor) sends out a few tees to their favourite customers and not only do people wear them, but they usually post pics to their social media or blog. Bugcrowd customers wear their Bugcrowd tees to big tech security conventions because they're in the minority; they're the outsiders; they're the marginalised, non-corporate misfits in tech security. They want to find each other and grow stronger through being together - like sports team supporters at an away game.

Story continues on page 2. Please click below.

Brand without logos

A new Manchester United supporter is joining a worldwide community of millions with a heritage going back generations. They know what it means to be a supporter and who their community expects them to be. They'll wear the team's brand with confidence because the last thing a football team ever does is dramatically change what it stands for and who it represents. If a team moves to a new city, takes on a foreign owner, or moves upmarket, it's a really, really big issue and generally a last resort.

In tech, even where we have a decade of cultural history to draw upon, it's usually included several dramatic shifts in direction and character. More tech companies get acquired or fail in five years than IPO. Sometimes it's a last resort, but more often it's the nature of the industry to change rapidly to seek new opportunities and technologies.

That constant change means a supporter isn't so certain exactly which community they're joining. They're not so ready to wear your brand.

But they might be prepared to wear a t-shirt like Bugcrowd's, which mainly features a tech security in-joke ("My other computer is your computer"). If you can brand the merchandise with something that relates to the community they're part of, rather than the brand of your tech company, you're going to see better results.

They might be prepared to wear a tee or hoodie in a brand colour if you feel you can own that brand colour over time, and they may be prepared to wear the brand if it's small and subtle. They might be interested in something truly unique - not just branded but completely new-like a new take on scarves, or hats, or jackets.

It's not a numbers game

On the playing field of a sporting stadium, I'm sure it feels like the team with the most fans has an advantage. But remember, this is not about the team, it's about the supporters. When trying to turn your customers into fanatic supporters, it's not a numbers game, it's an allegiance game. In the stadium stands, it's the supporters of the underdog team who are most likely to shout louder, try harder, and band together in unity.

So when you're planning your supporter merchandise, don't be an economist - don't decide to produce the maximum amount of merchandise at the lowest cost. Don't keep it all in a warehouse, only bring it to trade shows, and then employ tradeshow trash to hand it out to every stranger to happens to wander by.

Tradeshow trash

Tradeshow trash don't represent your customer community. Lowest-cost scratchy Chinese cotton tees don't make any customer feel like you care about their support. And seeing them being handed out to people who are clearly not supporters is the last straw in supporter alienation.

Instead, produce a limited quantity of high-quality merchandise. Make customers earn the right to wear it - not by tweeting about how awesome your products are but by really relating to your community - helping contribute to FAQs, helping other customers with a question, volunteering to host a customer meetup. Make other customers aspire to get one too.

Every team's supporter community has a small set of hard-core, diehard fans at its very centre, and when you begin creating a supporter base for your tech startup brand, the first people to recruit are a small group of time-rich, no-friend, slightly mad customers looking for a chance to be the hard-core, diehard fans at the centre of a new team.

Uber Melbourne, by the way, didn't give any of us tees at the party. Maybe they knew we hadn't earned it and hopefully it knows we're way too cool to wear it ... yet.

Alan Jones is an ex-Yahoo product guy,@startmate   @pollenizerinvestor/mentor, and co-founder of   @thenewagencyAU.

Here's the full report.2013-12-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:28ZLexisNexisTECH SURVEYFINANCIAL PLANNINGPg. 54What's New in Tech?Among the BIG Trends identified in Financial Planning's latest Tech Survey: movement toward the cloud, better B-D technology & shifts in CRM, portfolio and rebalancing software. Here's the full report.Joel Bruckenstein

The move to the cloud is finally taking place. In category after category of this year's Financial Planning Tech Survey, we found software providers making the shift, and advisors responding. In CRM software, cloud-based providers are gaining share at the expense of desktop-based products; in portfolio management, advisors are moving to a hosted solution where a cloud version is unavailable.

Advisors report that mobile devices like smartphones rank in the top three among technology shifts that have benefited their firms most. Even the growing use of online file-sharing services helps unlock the handcuffs chaining advisors to their desks.

The following pages contain more details on the tools advisors are using to boost efficiency and client satisfaction. Other changes are afoot as well, of course. This year's study pointed to marketplace changes in CRM, rebalancing and portfolio technology. Advisor satisfaction with broker-dealer technology also seems to be on the mend.

A few notes on methodology: The survey was conducted in October. To prevent any ballot-box stuffing, Financial Planning sent out thousands of individual-use links to advisors; we got more than 1,100 responses, several times the number need to ensure statistical accuracy, according to polling experts.

We dissected the results by business model to get a feel for the similarities and differences in the way independent RIAs differ in their approach from hybrid advisors and those linked to independent broker- dealers. We also added a new level of analysis this year, exploring how firms of varying sizes (as measured by AUM) differ in their technology decisions.

WHO'S SPENDING?

One thing that we wanted to gauge at the outset was whether advisors were as willing to spend on technology as they were last year. Apparently, they are: Those who expect their technology budgets to grow in 2014 is flat (35% versus 36% last year), as is the relatively small slice who expect their budgets to shrink.

The results suggest that advisors understand that technology is an investment in their business as opposed to an expense, and that it will pay dividends. What we did not know, but often assumed, is that behaviors would differ across firm size.

We can now confirm this: Noticeably fewer (27.5%) of the smallest firms, with less than $10 million in AUM, are likely to increase tech spending in 2014. One possible reason is that capital may be tight at smaller firms; the other is that technology enhancements may not provide as much operational leverage.

Indeed, the firms most likely (41.5%) to increase tech spending in 2014 are those managing between $50 million and $99.9 million in assets. That's unsurprising: Firms of this size have the scale to truly benefit from technology investments, and if they are growing, may not have invested as deeply when they were smaller. This bodes well for broker-dealers, custodians and vendors who serve this segment, which accounted for about 12% of our respondents.

CRM CHANGES AFOOT

One place the cloud shift is evident is in the CRM category, where we see a slow but clear trend toward more modern cloud-based tools and away from desktop-server-based systems. Redtail made some incremental gains in share this year, as did Salesforce and Tamarac Advisor CRM, to cite a few examples. Meanwhile, older technologies slipped: ACT! dropped to a 7% share from 9% last year and ACT4Advisors dropped to 1.2% from 2%, with weak showings for both among independent RIAs. Goldmine fell, as well.

Junxure, a former darling among sophisticated independent RIAs, showed some slippage, as did ProTracker. Both are about to release totally new cloud versions of their software, and it will be interesting to see the impact of these releases. We think both will attract some serious attention.

Redtail, the overall leader among real CRM systems, did particularly well with hybrids, although it also had strong usage among independent broker-dealer reps and RIAs. And Micro- soft Outlook still gets too many votes in our survey, but its share is way down from last year (22.2% versus 35%), suggesting that advisors are finally beginning to realize that Outlook is no substitute for a real CRM system. (Although almost a third of the smallest firms are still using Outlook.)

We've long theorized that Redtail is most popular at the low end of the AUM scale and least popular at the high end. Redtail is inexpensive, which appeals to smaller firms with smaller tech budgets, and it is not as robust as some of the more expensive systems. But Redtail has been getting a steady stream of incremental upgrades, making it a more powerful product than it was a few short years ago.

Probably for that reason, we found we were only partly right. Redtail did score poorly among firms with more than $500 million in AUM, but the group with the next lowest usage was firms with less than $10 million in AUM. The highest Redtail usage was in the $25 million to $49.9 million group, and it fared almost as well among firms with $100 million to $499.9 million. We only saw a substantial shrinkage in market share among the biggest firms.

When we sliced the CRM market share based on compensation models, we found that fee-only advisors were more likely to use Junxure, Salentica and Tamarac Advisor CRM, while ACT!, Advisors Assistant and Ebix scored substantially better with hybrid advisors. Redtail did a bit better with the fee and commission crowd, but exhibited good strength across both roles, as did Salesforce.

REBALANCING SOFTWARE

Rebalancing software has become a growth segment of the market. Although 60.6% of advisors are not using any rebalancing software at all, that number is markedly lower than last year's 69%. And the bigger the firm, the more likely it is to use rebalancing software: Less than half of firms with more than $500 million in AUM have not purchased rebalancing software, compared with 78.1% of the smallest firms.

No surprise there: The better programs, which feature both tax and location sensitivity, tend to be pricey, and advisors who are only monitoring a limited number of accounts might believe (mistakenly, in our view) that they don't need this type of software.

Last year, we did not include Morningstar Office in the rebalancing category; this year, we did - and it debuts in the top spot. Morningstar only rebalances at the account level, not at the client or household level, and it is not tax aware, so it is no competition for the more sophisticated products, but it is apparently sufficient for many advisors, across all AUM levels. One reason may be that the tool is included as part of the Morningstar Office package.

Among the more robust products, Tamarac leads with a 3.8% share, and with almost all its users above the $100 million AUM cutoff. The same can be said for iRebal.

We also asked about iRebal Cloud, because we expected it to be available to all TD Ameritrade advisors by the time of the survey, but the general release has been delayed, so the user base was insignificant. We expect it to be very popular with advisors that custody exclusively with TD Ameritrade.

TABLETS & SMARTPHONES

It should come as no surprise that, as the cloud shift continues and advisors are less tied to their desks, mobile adoption grew, as well. This year, 58.8% of advisors told us they use a tablet for business, up from about 50% last year. Of those, 77.5% use an iPad and 18.6% use an Android tablet. The surprise here was the Windows tablet showing; 11.5% of the tablet users say they use one.

It is also interesting to note the usage variations by type of advisor. For example, 22% of CPA advisors who own a tablet for work use a Windows tablet, as do 15.4% of insurance advisors. And insurance agents are just as likely to own an Android tablet as they are an iPad.

Smartphone adoption is still growing, too, with 87% of advisors now saying they use a smartphone for work; that's up from 80% last year. The iPhone is the dominant brand, with a 62.3% share, followed by Android at 35.9% and BlackBerry still in the mix at 8.8% - with its users dominated by bank advisors and broker-dealer employees. It is worth noting that while Windows tablets surprised us on the upside, Windows phones did not, showing a mere 2.1% share.

SOCIAL MEDIA

Speaking broadly, social media adoption appears to have plateaued. The numbers from this year for the most used outlets (LinkedIn, Facebook, Twitter, Google+ and YouTube) are remarkably similar to last year's.

When you break those numbers down by revenue, however, some interesting patterns emerge. The smallest firms (those with less than $10 million in AUM) made greater use of every single social media platform we asked about - by a significant margin in some cases. For example, the smallest firms were almost twice as likely as the average firm to use Google+, and about 40% more likely than average to use Facebook.

There could be multiple explanations: Many of these firms are new, so in some cases they may be run by younger, more tech-savvy advisors. And social media is an inexpensive way for startups to build brand awareness.

Or course, there's another plausible explanation (although we hope this is not the case): inexperience may mean they are less aware of the regulations and requirements with regard to social media usage.

There were other marked differences in social media use. Independent RIAs are the leaders here - significantly more likely to use Twitter, for instance, and somewhat more likely to use Facebook, LinkedIn and YouTube. This is probably because they have more control over their own compliance policies, and because there are numerous low-cost compliance/archiving technologies available to them.

FINANCIAL PLANNING MISS?

One area where software use showed a disappointing decline was in financial planning tools, where 30.6% of respondents said they are not using financial planning software - up from 26% last year. That's a shame, we think, because many financial planning software packages are more user-friendly, making it easier and faster than ever to provide meaningful results to a body of clients who badly need it.

It's worth noting that a whopping 57.5% of commission-based advisors do not use financial planning software.

MoneyGuidePro continues its dominance this year with a 22% market share, with consistently high usage across firms of all sizes. The No. 2 product, eMoney, was also consistent across the AUM spectrum, with the exception of the smallest segment, where firms might consider eMoney too pricey.

Zywave's NaviPro Suite does well at firms with more than $50 million in AUM, but is strongest above the $500 million mark - no doubt because of its detailed cash flow planning capability. And we are keeping an eye on SunGard, which also seems to do better with higher-asset firms. After many years of stagnation, the firm is introducing new products again and refining existing ones.

PORTFOLIO COMPETITION

Portfolio management, with 23 products listed this year, is one of the most competitive software categories. A primary reason for this is money: Price tags in this category tend to be high, so software developers find it an attractive market. We also think that, with few exceptions, the reporting capabilities of vendors in this space lag advisor expectations - as well as those of their clients - by a significant margin. For these reasons, we expect new products to continue to launch in this space.

As was the case last year, Morningstar and Albridge dominated the rankings, although the gap has closed a bit this year. Albridge, which has always had a strong focus on the institutional side of the business, gets the majority of its business from advisors who charge a combination of fees and commissions, with most of the remainder coming from commission-only advisors. But Morningstar Office users were fairly evenly split among the compensation models.

Dominant products for fee-only advisors - by a wide margin - were Schwab's PortfolioCenter and Advent Axys. Addepar, which has generated a lot of industry buzz, had only a 0.1% share in its survey debut.

Albridge's former CEO told us that he struggled to find a cost-effective service model for independent RIAs. But change may be coming. Pershing veteran Marc Butler is now a managing director at Albridge, and we expect the company to release a totally new version of its portfolio software in the first half of 2014.

Because Schwab is the largest custodian to independent RIAs, it makes sense that PortfolioCenter shows strength in that sector. Over the last several years, however, the product seems to be slipping in the rankings, which we attribute to advisors' dissatisfaction with the application's reporting capabilities. Schwab is aware of the complaints; we expect it to launch a new application to address the issue, but probably not till sometime in 2015.

TECHNOLOGY SATISFACTION

Compared with the custodians for independent advisors, broker-dealers have lagged for years in technology satisfaction. But the B-Ds' technology fortunes appear to be rising, suggesting that they've discovered what the RIA custodians figured out a few years ago: Good technology increases efficiency and client satisfaction.

No B-D has a higher percentage of very satisfied advisors than Raymond James, where a significant investment in technology over the last several years is paying off. The percentage of respondents who are very satisfied with Raymond James technology doubled this year to 42.7%.

NFP's gains are impressive, as well, with the B-D more than doubling the percentage of very satisfied advisors to 39% from 16.9%. Other B-Ds with a high percentage of very satisfied advisors include Securities America (38.5%) and Cambridge Investment Research (37.8%).

Among the custodians, TD Ameritrade leads the pack, with 47.6% of their advisors saying they're very satisfied with the technology. Much of this is due to the very popular VEO Open Access integration initiative, but TD's decision to release a free, cloud-based version of iRebal to advisors next year no doubt helped perceptions, as well.

Schwab is within striking distance, with 44.0% of very satisfied advisors. Fidelity is third at 36.2%.

Among the custodians with a reputation for welcoming small advisors, TradePMR scored the best. We believe the company's new Fusion platform will propel it to even better scores next year, but this year's transition from the old platform may have held back scores. Shareholders Service Group came in a strong second.

TECH HYPE

One new area we studied this year was the link between hype and awareness of some new technology products. Because we've often been surprised by the disproportionate attention some unproven new technologies have received, we wanted to find out whether a few heavily covered new products had actually gained high brand awareness - or use.

We selected three new products: Blueleaf, InStream and Market 76. We expected to find that a significant proportion of readers were at least familiar with the brands.

That turned out not to be the case: Fewer than 10% of respondents had heard of Market 76, fewer than 15% had heard of InStream and fewer than 20% of readers knew Blueleaf. Usage ranked from 0.2% for Market 76 to a high of 0.8% for InStream.

Since all three providers started out as either free or low-cost solutions, we thought that smaller advisors, with their smaller tech budgets, might have greater familiarity with these firms.

We were wrong. Across all three products, advisors with less than $25 million in AUM were less likely than the average reader to have heard of these firms.

OPERATING SYSTEMS

Another area of change is operating systems. Last year, we commented on the high number of Windows XP machines that were still in use. That operating system is more than a decade old, and Microsoft will stop supporting Windows XP in April.

Thankfully, advisors are starting to heed the call to upgrade. Just 22.3% of respondents said they have an XP machine, versus 37% last year. We optimistically (perhaps we hould say foolishly) hope that number drops to zero by April.

We also expect Windows 8 to continue to climb in market share. While Windows 7 usage has remained steady, 21.7% of respondents now have at least one Windows 8 machine, up from none last year.

ONGOING CONCERNS

Although the overall technology picture is positive, there are some issues that continue to worry us.

Advisor satisfaction with integration remains low. Only 14.9% of advisors are very satisfied with integration, with 26% either somewhat or very dissatisfied.

Another worry: 43% of advisors say they evaluate technology based on cost alone, compared with only 9.6% that do a formal ROI analysis. That suggests that advisors may be making poor decisions.

That said, when we asked which technology had the greatest impact on your firm over the past year, advisors cited CRM tools, financial planning software and smartphones - all of which sounds good to us, as advisors work to improve both efficiency and client relationships.

It's also worth noting that there are a few things that don't show up in this year's survey, largely because of timing. Some promising new firms aren't mentioned because they have not built a meaningful market share.

Among the new cloud-based CRM products, Junxure Cloud's delayed general release made it a very minor presence; we expect to see much better numbers next year. We also left ProTracker Cloud off the survey because it was not yet available, but it will be by the time you read this; we'll be reporting next year on how it performs.

We're also curious about attitudes toward Windows 8. More than 22% of respondents said they were using the operating system, with only 14% planning to switch this year - but the survey closed the day before Windows 8.1 was released. We wonder if the upgrade, which returns the Start button and allows users to choose a more familiar Windows look and feel, will persuade more advisors to switch.

Although technology advances for financial advisors are often slower and more painful than some would like, the overall trends are positive.

Generally speaking, advisors are moving to the cloud and leveraging mobile more than they did a year or two ago. Broker-dealers and custodians are investing heavily in new technologies and being rewarded with higher satisfaction ratings, a trend we expect to continue into 2014. Third-party vendors are investing in technology, too, and we expect a number of new and interesting firms to come to market next year.

Challenges remain, but the industry is making progress.

Joel Bruckenstein, a Financial Planning columnist in Miramar, Fla., is co-creator of the Technology Tools for Today conference series and technology guides for advisors, including Technology Tools for Today's High-Margin Practice. For more information, visit JoelBruckenstein.com.

6 BIG TECH TRENDS FOR 2014

THE SURVEY LOOKS BACK. WE LOOK AHEAD.

The survey data tells us what's been going on this past year, but it doesn't tell you what's going to happen next year. Here are a few modest technology predictions for 2014.

1. Continued cloud migration: A no-brainer. While many advisors continue to express reservations about cloud-based technologies, we believe the shift is inevitable. For firms with less than $1 billion in AUM, the business case is compelling: They can outsource hardware, software, maintenance, backups and - to a large extent - disaster recovery. (The case is less clear-cut for larger firms, which can justify a full-time in-house IT department, but there are still advantages.) Meanwhile, most new advisor software is cloud-based, offering advisors an ever-expanding selection of applications.

2. Better, deeper integrations: There was a time when a vendor could claim that integration meant a pair of data moves - an export to Excel, and then an import from Excel to the application - and many advisors would accept it. Those days are gone. Advisors now expect true, seamless two-way data transmission between applications. Progress is uneven and there is still a real challenge moving some types of data due to a lack of data standards. Still, we expect further gains in the coming year as more products shift to cloud-based technology, which simplifies connections between different products.

3. Heavy investments from custodians and IBDs: While the details differ by firm, just about every firm we talk to is spending heavily on advisor technology. LPL, the largest player in the independent B-D space, devoted an unprecedented amount of time to technology at its annual conference this year. It is rolling out new technologies that are significantly better than previous generations, and doing so much more rapidly than in the past. Virtually the same can be said for its major competitors. All of the major RIA custodians are set to enhance their technology offerings, as well. Improvements include deeper integration with third-party providers, improved trading platforms and more powerful and user-friendly mobile apps for both advisors and their end clients.

4. Security concerns persist: The financial services industry will continue to be attacked by shady characters. It is too big a target to ignore. Years ago, boutique RIA firms might fly under the radar of thieves, but today's search engines and databases make it easy for malicious individuals to identify likely targets in a geographic area. It's also worth noting that many of the security threats now facing firms are behavioral as well as technological: An employee may pick up a malicious USB drive in the parking lot, plug it into an office computer and unleash a virus; or an advisor might click on a link from an email that appears to be from a client. Another common problem involves wire fraud: These scams usually begin when a client's email account gets hijacked by a hacker, who then asks an advisor to complete a wire transfer to a third party.

5. Data power: There is a great deal of useful data on the servers of advisory firms, custodians and clearing firms, but historically, that data has not been available to advisors in a usable format. That will change in 2014. Pershing and Fidelity have both created new interfaces to make analytics available to advisors in an easy-to-digest format. Envestnet/Tamarac has made similar capabilities available to users, and a number of CRM firms - including Junxure, Redtail and various versions of Salesforce - either already or will soon contain analytics dashboards. This type of information will help advisors run their businesses more efficiently and improve the experience they provide to the end client. Which brings us to ...

6. Better client experience: Competition from online consumer platforms like Mint and Personal Capital means advisors cannot be complacent about the technology they use to interact with their clients. Consumers want clear, concise, interactive digital reporting; advisor websites must be engaging, easy to navigate and mobile compatible. Fortunately, B-Ds, custodians and vendors will be delivering more tools to help advisors provide a better client experience. Many planning firms will also improve their web presence and create branded mobile apps for their clients. -Joel Bruckenstein

THINK LIKE A STARTUP

My firm is four years old and manages $675 million in assets. Yet even now, we still deliberately try to think like a startup - and we think this is key to our firm's success.

I was talking to a peer at an industry event recently and told her we were making a major software switch for both our portfolio reporting and CRM solution.

She shook her head. Though she seemed envious of the integration of our new platform, she also said her firm, which is much older, could never make such a switch. "We have too much history with our systems," she said, "and converting would be near impossible."

Her words stayed with me. I began to wonder: What would happen if the people at Glassman Wealth Services stopped thinking like a startup? What would happen if all the things we love about working here simply eroded over time - because we got too big or too "mature," or had too much history to make changes?

That was a scary thought. But it also reminded me that, regardless of how big we get, we can't lose the entrepreneurial mind-set that got us where we are.

Fortunately, there are things that every small business owner - yes, even planners - can do to keep the entrepreneurial fires burning.

The best way to approach this is to liken these decisions to a home renovation.

Some decisions are as easy as redecorating or painting - like changing your marketing campaign to include a newsletter, or adding a blog to your website. At the other end of spectrum are the boundaries of the lot - the deal-breakers that would cause one to sell the home and move. For us, this boundary includes our fee-only fiduciary status and our culture.

Then there are those decisions that are like load-bearing walls. These are essential to the structure of the home, but what if that structure just isn't working anymore? They are messy and costly to move, but the work is doable.

In our firm, we are not afraid of shifting a few load-bearing walls. We consider the costs and understand that the mess will cause discomfort, but that's not what we focus on.

Instead, we ask ourselves: Will the cost and mess improve the client experience? Will the change make us more competitive?

We saw our CRM and portfolio management system as load-bearing walls - and decided that the expense and the six-month effort would both improve our operations significantly and give our clients many benefits that our previous system couldn't provide.

It's important to ask yourself: What decisions do you consider to be load bearing? Are they legitimately that difficult?

Inertia, bureaucracy or the acceptance of the status quo can prevent your firm from growing in efficient and profitable ways - and can prove fatal to your business.

My peer made the mistake of thinking that the reason we were able to change our software system was because we were relatively new. But the truth is that we were able to make that change because we nurture our nimble entrepreneurial mind-set and encourage the type of startup thinking that allows us to embrace change and opportunity. And that's something we'll strive to do no matter how large we get.

Barry Glassman, CFP, is founder and president of Glassman Wealth Services, an investment and wealth management firm in McLean, Va.

Discover the materials, fabrics, retail technologies and up-and-coming athletes that will impact the future of the industry.

team sports

Have you ever heard of apparel that will moisturize your skin? A piece of sports equipment made from sponge metal? A sporting goods store without a cashier? A 14-year-old millionaire athlete?

Although all of the above may sound like the delirious ramblings of tired editors, these things have already--or will soon--blink into existence. In this special feature, SGB explores the key developments and trends that are destined to drive the sporting goods industry forward.

Still skeptical? The moisturizing fabric is Skintex and it's made by Cognis. The cashierless technology is called RFID (radio frequency identification). The 14-year-old athlete is Freddy Adu, a soccer player who signed a multi-million-dollar pro contract with MLS. Okay, sponge metal hasn't hit the sports equipment market yet. But it is currently being used in the aerospace industry, so it's only a matter of time.

Remember, the future is all about possibility.

**********

T3K Just Warming Up

NFL Star Tackling Sudden Success in the Performance Apparel Category

Making a splash in the performance apparel business was not one of the challenges Simeon Rice anticipated when he began his NFL career in 1996. Yet here Rice is, the driving force behind T3K, one of the breakthrough brands of 2003.

* BIRTH OF A BRAND The idea for T3K (short for THERMAL 3000) came to Rice at the end of the 1999 season, when his Arizona Cardinals were scheduled to play the Green Bay Packers on the frozen turf of Lambeau Field. Unhappy with the insulating garments supplied by the club--and two sacks shy of setting a franchise record--the cat-quick pass rush specialist pieced together a crude neoprene body suit before the game. Rice stayed warm, got his two sacks and took the first steps toward building a business that, four years later, has the trade truly excited.

* PRODUCT EVOLUTION Rice continued to tinker with the concept of a clothing line engineered to keep athletes warm when they are out in the cold. From a bulky, handmade prototype, he honed his original idea into a sleek, insulating undergarment that he and several of his fellow Tampa Bay Buccaneers wore during a cold-weather showdown with the Philadelphia Eagles in last year's NFC Championship Game. Rice--who went on to earn a Super Bowl ring--believes his bodywear played a key role in the Bucs' 27-10 victory.

* BUILDING THE LINE Rice began assembling a team to manufacture, market and sell T3K shortly after the Super Bowl. He partnered with Style Up America, a Los Angeles-based apparel manufacturer that could work with advanced performance materials and could assemble the garments with indestructible flatlock stitching. The line includes light-yet-durable tops, bottoms and headgear.

* FEATURES & BENEFITS "There were three key issues we had to deal with before launching the brand," says Rice, who demanded that T3K move with the body, while keeping athletes warm and dry. "We needed seams that would stand up to the kind of forces generated in pro football or pro hockey. We also had to build moisture-moving and temperature-regulating properties into the line to ensure peak performance for the athletes who wear it. The durability issue was solved through the flatlock stitching process, which creates a seam that is virtually indestructible. The comfort issues were addressed through high-tech linings bonded to T3K's insulating outer layer."

* INDUSTRY BUZZ The fact that an NFL superstar was launching a line of insulating performance undergarments created much excitement in the apparel industry. When T3K began shipping in the fall, the feedback was overwhelmingly positive. The line is simply styled, well priced, and--most important--performs as advertised.

* T3K IN 2004 In 2004, the company will add a new line using a dual-layer radial knit technical fabric that offers moisture management that is superior to most products currently on the market. The new material is being used in T3K's bodywear, as well as several new styles, including a traditional golf shirt.

[ILLUSTRATION OMITTED]

[ILLUSTRATION OMITTED]

Contact info: website: www.t3kwear.com ; telephone: (866) 53K-Wear

Four Questions for Simeon Rice

[ILLUSTRATION OMITTED]

Q: How does T3K fit into the big picture for Simeon Rice?

A: I am the roots and my business ventures are the branches. As for T3K, I will be involved in the development and promotion of the brand the same way I was involved in its conception, design and engineering: 100 percent, all-out, all the way.

Q: Is your goal to grow T3K as a non-football-identified brand?

A: That's correct. Ultimately, people will buy T3K not because "football star Simeon Rice" says it works, but because it works. Period. We're already seeing that in our initial orders--a very small percentage is being generated by football accounts.

Q: How would you characterize the manufacturing, sales and marketing team you've built around this brand?

A: Experienced, creative, intelligent, honest--people who are focused on the same goal, who know how to develop markets and service accounts, people who pay attention to the details.

Q: What is the most valuable piece of advice you have received in your business career?

A: Actually, it was a piece of "life" advice from my father. He said, "Simeon, don't wait for life to dictate what it wants from you, you dictate what you want from life." It has helped me maintain control in a crazy business, set high standards for myself and others, and freed me to explore places--like the performance apparel business--that I never expected to go.

T3K SCORING WITH OUTDOOR RETAILERS

Identifying new markets is priority one in the performance apparel business, especially if your company is just getting in the game. That has been the focus of the T3K sales and marketing staff from the very beginning, when owner and NFL star Simeon Rice made it crystal clear that this was not to be a "football-only" brand. According to National Sales Manager Paul Andre, fulfilling Rice's vision has not exactly been a problem. "New markets are finding T3K," he says. "When word spread on how well this product performed, we began seeing orders from accounts we never expected. Mountain climbers have picked up on T3K, as have the hunters and fishing enthusiasts."

According to Andre, T3K has also proved an ideal fit for the equestrian market, where there is a demand for lightweight, heat-conserving garments that also allow for full range of motion. For similar reasons, the outdoor business--particularly hunting and fishing--have been drawn to the product. Andre adds that T3K's sales efforts are also expanding to "non-sports" applications.

HOCKEY JOCK CHECKS IN WITH THE PROS

Within the traditional sports business, T3K's strongest market may be hockey. The company will debut a line of hockey jocks in 2004, with Tampa Bay Lightning All-Star Vincent Lecavalier serving as its endorsing athlete. Claude Gagnon, who is helping to spearhead T3K's hockey business, expects the line to grow rapidly in popularity.

"Many pros are already wearing the T3K hockey jock," he reports. "Orders were placed back in the fall by several NHL teams. They love it."

"As new markets continue to emerge for T3K," says Rice, "we are prepared to design products--as we did for hockey--that meet the unique demands of each."

[ILLUSTRATION OMITTED]

INTO THE MATRIX

Hockey sticks, tennis racquets, golf clubs, bikes, skis and sneakers are certainly indispensable pieces of sports equipment. But so, too, are test tubes, beakers, wind tunnels, machine shops and compression machines. After all, a product's performance characteristics depend on the materials from which it is made, and without lab testing and scientific innovation, sporting goods manufacturers, retailers and consumers would be all the poorer.

"Sporting goods companies are looking for technical edges." says Dr. Kim B. Blair, director of MIT's Center for Sports Innovation. "The Internet has pushed the average expectation of performance up. People are used to technology in their lives and they expect it in products--they demand more performance."

Blair launched the MIT Center for Sports Innovation in August 1999 with a mission to provide students with hands-on experience in sports product development, with a focus on end-use application. Sporting goods manufacturers benefit because the students can provide research quickly and relatively inexpensively. New Balance, Trek, K2, Lange, Wilson and Easton are among the companies that have used this resource.

While countless materials exist that could conceivably boost product performance, sporting goods RD & D experts tend to focus on those that will affect lightness, strength, vibration control and grip. Current examples include carbon fiber, metal alloys, liquid metal (an amorphous metal that forms easily to different shapes and has good rebound properties), as well as a plethora of polymers, resins, ceramics, composites and glasses.

"Many of the advancements are coming out of the aerospace industry, and we'll also see bleed-over technology from high-tech industries," notes Blair. "Right now, carbon fiber has a heavy market pull because consumers are demanding lighter, better performance." However, he notes, "Carbon fiber can get stiffness and resilience into desired areas, but sporting goods companies need to be careful where they use carbon fiber or other materials."

Although a particular material may be strong--usually a desired characteristic--it may also be brittle or heavy. "Often, if a material solves a huge problem, it may cause others," explains Win Fream, project manager at Bauer Nike Hockey. For this reason, mixing and matching materials, and developing new processes, are gaining importance.

Matt Arndt, director of baseball and softball products at Easton, concurs. "Lightweight and strength are two must-haves, but they work against each other. Basically, stronger is heavier. But with [new materials], we can achieve strength with lighter weight." He adds, "Metal technology and composites are amazing. A lot of R & D now concerns combinations of materials [such as] carbon, glass, resin and composites." The question, he says, is how to put these together in a way that's compatible.

"Performance improvements are coming from mixed material combinations--such as mixed alloy frames on bikes--rather than from a totally new material by itself," explains Blair. "People are playing with foam metals and metal sandwich constructions in the aerospace industry, but these haven't hit sporting goods yet." Incidentally, foam metal looks like a sponge, but is metallic. It offers stiffness without a lot of weight.

[ILLUSTRATION OMITTED]

Blair points out that many companies are now looking at polymers for use in such products as bike frames and tennis racquets because of their vibration-dampening abilities. Polymers are also being used in grip tapes because of their non-slip, friction-absorption properties. "Anytime you have vibration, it annoys the athlete and impedes performance," Blair says.

According to Fream, it is more important to look at how materials affect performance features and serve the needs of the consumer than at how a material fits into a specific product. "Materials are generally chosen for their aesthetics, expense, and playability/performance. We also look at marketability issues," he says.

In the never-ending pursuit of new materials, RD & D gurus often take a "blue sky" approach by looking beyond the sporting goods sector and into other realms such as the aerospace, automotive, medical and high-tech industries. In addition, suppliers, frequently seeking to capitalize on their own R & D investments, bring new materials to sporting goods manufacturers.

"Easton develops a lot of materials and we get actively involved with suppliers rather than just taking what's offered," says Arndt. "Having a staff that's able to do this--such as metallurgists and chemists--helps enormously."

Additionally, manufacturers are not shy about approaching their vendors with specific needs and requests. "If we need something to stick together, we call DuPont--they're great at that," remarks Fream.

And lest anyone forget, "There are a lot of entrepreneurs out there, too, who have new products and concepts," Blair says. "And a lot of ideas come from the athletes themselves." By surveying this broad landscape and then bringing new materials in-house and experimenting with them, sporting goods companies are able to offer real innovation.

"What drives the industry is finding new designs and materials that allow changes in a product design. It is important to allow R & D to focus on a material in general, and then apply it to a product," says Arndt.

Moreover, asserts Brian Dillman, Wilson's VP of global marketing, "Knowing the sport and knowing the way you want a product to perform determines the materials." He notes that Wilson typically spends nine months to two years testing materials in a given product. "Materials and designs will drive the industry in the next few years," he says.

While gaining access to the latest and greatest materials is of paramount importance, so is cost--particularly in the sporting goods industry, which is known for having low margins. So, does unobtanium's high price put it totally out of reach of the market? Not necessarily.

"You don't close your eyes to how much a material costs, but if it has a significant impact on product performance, you try to pursue it," says Fream. "Most advances in materials move down-market as they get older in the product line." Blair notes that improvements of traditional materials also help bring lower-priced "exotics" into products.

"If a new material allows you to make a better product, the product will tend to be high-end and the market will usually accept it," Arndt says. "It all depends on what product the materials will be going into."

Arndt points to Easton's use of Scandium (an aluminum alloy) in baseball bats to increase batting power as such an example. "It took Easton a year and a half to put Scandium into its products, but now the material is almost commonplace in the baseball bat market," he says. "Bats have gotten so good that leagues and sports governing bodies have imposed performance limitations. As a result, comfort, swing weight, feel and durability have become the most important properties."

With increasing numbers of new materials, material mixes and processes becoming more readily available, product customization figures to be the next big trend on the horizon. "Personalized design is coming, but the tools are not quite ready yet," comments Blair. "It's an obvious extension of custom fit, especially in bikes." At present, categories holding the most customization potential include golf, tennis and bike.

"The sooner sporting goods manufacturers can start addressing personalization, the better," asserts Blair. "There is a huge market for weekend warriors in terms of improved, high-end performance."

--JUDY LEAND

FEEL-GOOD FUTURE

Activewear that delivers spa-like benefits? Bio-based fibers that feel like cashmere? Technical outerwear held together with glue? These concepts may sound far-fetched, but they are planned for the very near future.

Textile companies around the globe are bringing a whole new set of innovations to market. From fibers to fabrics to garment construction, the latest technologies are broadening the scope of apparel properties like never before. By borrowing from other industries, and/or tapping into fresh resources, suppliers are creating products that greatly exceed traditional clothing characteristics of warmth and weather protection.

Advances in micro-encapsulation and nanotechnology are opening the door for fabrics that have a wide range of extended performance features--such as clothing that does everything from moisturize and massage the skin to help alleviate the symptoms of a cold. New fabric finishes will update everyday apparel with high-tech performance. Common apparel annoyances like stains, odors, wrinkles, fading and static cling will all soon be things of the past.

New construction techniques are also emerging. Growing interest in adhesive bonding is changing the look and feel of garments while simultaneously offering manufacturing efficiencies. The result is super-lightweight, sleek-looking, smooth-to-the-skin apparel with speed-to-market availability.

For instance, a new bonding product called Sewfree has rapidly caught the attention of several industries. In just three years, this bonding film, which launched in lingerie and moved on to applications in lifestyle and athletic wear, is now showing up in technical outerwear.

"I can't say adhesives will replace sewing, but it will certainly compliment sewing and provide exciting options," says Chris Parlee, director of marketing and promotions for Bemis, the Shirley, MA, firm that developed Sewfree. The company recently opened a Hong Kong office to service the growing demand for its film in apparel end uses.

[ILLUSTRATION OMITTED]

WHAT'S HOT

Textile companies seem especially keen on performance categories that boast naturally derived fibers, wellness features, and specialty properties.

"Just look at the success of the grocery chain Whole Foods and the cosmetic line Aveda. That trend of environmental awareness translates to textiles," explains Karla Magruder, who has spent her textile career bringing new products to market. She says that right now, consumers want things that don't hurt the environment. Products to watch in this category are Cargill's Ingeo corn-based line, a new soy protein fiber from China, and a product from Scandinavia derived from moss.

Hindered in the past by less-than-appealing aesthetics, the latest crop of organic fibers has an improved hand. "The new soy product from China is being promoted as an alternative to cashmere," says Magruder, who recently established the firm Fabrikology in Hoboken, NJ, to focus on educating the trade on textile trends.

Wellness is another strong lifestyle trend with textile applications. Companies in the United States, Europe and Japan have recognized a consumer demand for clothes that deliver cosmetic and other well-being benefits. New apparel will be available that not only raises oxygen levels, but also reduces cellulite. Making news here are Lycra Body Care from Invista, Skintex from Cognis, and a new product from Austria called SeaCell that uses seaweed.

Lycra Body Care uses fiber micro-encapsulation technology to deliver moisturizing benefits. Moisturizing agents stored in the fiber structure--as many as a million microscopic capsules per square centimeter of fabric--break open and release their contents progressively as garments move against the skin, continuously hydrating it. Two nourishing formulas are available: skin moisturizing aloe vera, and chitosan, a marine extract with skin-soothing properties.

Lycra Body Care's massage properties are the result of combining textile compression technology and temperature management in special high-tech hosiery yarns. A gentle massaging action works vitamin-rich nutrients into the skin. Currently, this is a legwear product, but it has potential for other end uses.

Cognis, a global chemical supplier, has a new program that incorporates cosmetic ingredients into active clothes. Referred to as "Wellness to Wear," the product Skintex comes in a variety of compositions. These include moisturizers, anti-cellulite properties, a hair retardant and an ingredient that promotes tanning.

According to Cognis, which has offices in North Carolina, the garment is treated with microcapsules consisting of a core of active ingredients surrounded and protected by a natural polymer. When the microcapusles come into contact with the skin, the encapsulated actives are continuously transferred from the garment to the skin.

[ILLUSTRATION OMITTED]

[ILLUSTRATION OMITTED]

All sorts of textiles can be treated with Skintex with applications suitable for sportswear, hosiery and underwear. "We are able to use our expertise in the cosmetics business to develop textiles with new wellness characteristics," says Brian Francis, Cognis Corp.'s business manager for performance textiles. "We are dedicated to this market segment."

Schoeller also pinpoints health as a key direction for textiles in the future. The company plans to address this with a combination of technologies that integrate such things as vitamins and natural essences into fabrics." Just think if there was a shirt you could wear that would treat a cold," suggests Christine Jenny, chief relations officer at Schoeller AG, Switzerland.

Currently, Schoeller is making headlines with its innovations in nanotechnology. The Schoeller NanoSphere product repels heavy-duty stains like red wine and coffee, yet has the look and feel of sophisticated fabric. "The technology is very consumer-friendly," says Jenny. "People understand the benefits easily, unlike other new technologies that are not as visual."

Schoeller now applies nanotechnology to fabric. But Jenny believes the ability to apply the technology while in the yarn stage is a viable future development. "We view the potential for nanotechnology as almost endless," she says.

--EMILY WALZER

YOUNG, TALENTED AND NOT LEBRON

Any discussion of the next great sports star nowadays begins and ends with LeBron. But while the undeniably talented "King James" may be the only teenager out there with a $100 million Nike contract to his name, he's not the only young pup turning his chosen sport on its ear.

[ILLUSTRATION OMITTED]

The evolution of a young athlete from phenom to superstar to icon takes more than talent and marketing. Sometimes it coincides with the emergence of a genre of sport (Tony Hawk) or a confluence of cultural impact with record-breaking talent (Tiger). No doubt the next great superstar will be wealthy and famous. But it's the intangible qualities, not the fame, that makes a legend. There is even a chance the "next" great one may come from outside the traditional sports realm.

"At my school, kids are definitely into individual sports," says 14-year-old climbing wunderkind Daniel Woods, one of the athletes spotlighted above. "I don't really climb in order to get attention. When you see LeBron James it seems like he is doing all this just to make money and be famous, but I'm sure he also has a love for playing his sport."

Here's a look at a few athletes who are operating with slightly less fanfare than LeBron, but with unprecedented success.

--CARA GRIFFIN

RETAILERS GET TECHY

The merchants are finally entering the computer age. Many sporting goods chains have turned to technology to cut costs and automate back-office functions such as logistics, warehousing and transportation. But only recently have they started using technology in a big way to boost sales, and the rollout of these innovations promises to shake up how merchandising is being done on the sporting goods selling floor.

Some of this technology is out front, such as kiosks at REI delivering 45,000 pages of content online to help consumers find information about products and activities. Customer loyalty programs, now a primary customer retention tool, also have their foundation in technology, as do cash-generators such as store credit cards and gift cards.

But many of the advancements involve software that provides real-time tracking of inventories, sales transactions and purchase orders to help chains better plan assortments prior to the season, as well as react to in-season demand. Some of these tools also analyze pricing to uncover the optimal initial price when an item hits the selling floor, as well as the best prices for promotion and clearance.

The tools have already greatly improved collaboration between store managers and the corporate office for many chains as they move to a centralized inventory management system. Sales transactions were previously downloaded overnight, but are now updated every few minutes. This constant monitoring enables stores to react speedily to out-of-stock hot items, while also allowing them to pull back on orders and reduce markdowns of poor sellers.

Bernie Brennan, managing partner at Charlotte, NC-based SportsOneSource, says retailers are recognizing that markdowns are their largest expense, and are turning to merchandising and pricing software for help.

"It's really all about getting the assortments right at each store," says Brennan. "While it sounds basic, without contemporary systems, it's almost impossible."

For many chains, retailing becomes more complex as they expand. But merchandising has always been difficult because many categories are seasonal and others are fashion-driven, including sports teams becoming hot (or cold) overnight.

"You've got huge peaks in how this product gets bought," says Peter Charneff, chief product officer at JDA Software Group, which provides merchandising management systems for The Sport's Authority, Dick's, and Galyan's. "And the number of SKUs at some sporting goods chains is rivaling department stores, so you're getting into major assortment management."

At the same time, assortments have to be tailored to regional needs, a feat that becomes harder as chains expand across states. "The challenge is managing this very large assortment that needs to be somewhat localized," says Charneff.

Scott Friend, vice chairman and president of ProfitLogic, which provides merchandise optimization solutions, believes that the ability to better tailor assortments is critical in competing against Wal-Mart.

[ILLUSTRATION OMITTED]

"Wal-Mart is not about understanding their customer but is all about efficiency and delivering product at a low price," says Friend. "Specialty retailers such as sporting goods chains are in a unique position because their assortments are pretty narrow, and that puts them in a position to understand their customer on an intimate basis."

Hans Kantor, chief information officer at Modell's Sporting Goods, says a big win from of its recent shift to a centralized inventory system was gaining "real-time replenishment." This is particularly beneficial when dealing with events such as the Yankees' recent trip to the World Series.

"To be able to have my merchants watch POS transactions take place as they happen and react to it as far balancing inventories and ordering products is phenomenal," says Kantor.

The upgrade also allowed Modell's to enhance its frequent shopper program with an "instant gratification" benefit, whereby customers gain a pre-determined dollar-off coupon at the register when they make purchases beyond a set Modell's Value Plan (MVP) threshold.

REI reports that a switch to Marketmax's financial and assortment planning systems has allowed the chain to create better-targeted assortments for its customers in different regions. "Marketmax offers a nice bundle of tightly integrated applications," says John Strother, REI's director of inventory and logistics. "We go from an environment where data is entered in multiple spreadsheets and all tied together through people and a few batch applications, to an environment where you can count on data moving where you need it, when you need it."

Canada's Forzani Group last year rolled out a new POS system and a store WAN (wide area network) using VPN (virtual private network) technology in order to provide all stores access to the chain's centralized computer system.

"What this allows us to do is create web-based applications centrally so all stores can access them," said Debbie Gillis, Forzani's chief information officer. This enables to stores to look at inventory at other stores." Also, if there are any pricing or UPC questions, that can also be accessed centrally," Gillis adds.

Forzani's new systems will enable centralized returns, and many store reports and documents can be processed centrally. In 2004, Forzani will go live with JDA Portfolio Merchandise Management to upgrade its core systems and provide the foundation for efficiencies in supply chain and merchandise replenishment. Southern CA-based Chick's Sporting Goods revamped its back-office systems last year to improve inventory replenishment and open-to-buy management. "We became much more efficient at getting information out quicker to buyers, department managers and even vendors," says Erin Diebold, Chick's director of IS and accounting. Communications were improved between stores to enable centralized credit and check authorizations, and the chain also launched a successful gift card program.

In addition, Chick's recently rolled out e-mail to department managers to communicate transfer requests, as well as price changes and markdowns across the chain. Previously, such information was relayed by truck and this change allows Chick's buyers to quickly react to sales reports.

Salt Lake City-based Sportsman's Warehouse also noted a "180 degree turnaround" as it shifted to a centralized inventory system this year. The former system--which included nightly downloads that processed information from each store well into the next morning--become increasingly inefficient as the company added more stores. "Now we have real time information of everything that's happening at corporate and at the store level. We can move very quickly," says Mike Van Orden, Sportsman's chief technology officer.

Some chains are also putting tech-power behind their sales forces. In '04, Forzani will utilize labor scheduling software that allows stores to chart peak selling periods, thereby allowing retailers to make sure enough staff is on the sales floor at the right time.

At Modell's, an upgraded POS system will allow the chain to roll out wireless RF (radio frequency) guns, enabling store personal to quickly verify prices and process sales transactions.

A shift to wireless POS registers is allowing G.I. Joe's to hold an increasing number of outdoor events. "Wireless has become so much cheaper and so much more reliable," notes Marc Mieher, chief information officer at G.I. Joe's.

A seismic shift will come with the emergence of RFID (radio frequency identification), which promises to allow retailers to seamlessly track inventory from production to the retail selling floor. This technology, which is expected to replace the bar code, can scan a whole basket of goods in one swoop, and will drive self-checkout across retail. On the downside, a lofty price and lack of standards will likely delay the rollout of this technology until the latter part of this decade.

For now, the big tech payback is expected in merchandising, especially as retailers begin to capitalize on customer data mining with frequent-shopper programs and credit cards to create customer-specific marketing programs.

"The better you can get at your data, the better you can drive sales and profits," states Marketmax's Gene Gsell, chief marketing and sales officer at Marketmax.

--THOMAS J. RYANCopyright 2003 VNU Business Media4675

urn:contentItem:5WHH-1X61-JBKR-R2YF-00000-00What's next for amazon?2019-07-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:45:28ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. NP5What's next for amazon?Tom HogginsThe Daily Telegraph

By now, the birth of Amazon on July 5, 1994 is a well-worn tale. On that day 25 years ago, 30-year old "Wall Street whiz-kid" Jeff Bezos finally packed in his comfortable hedge fund job to set up an online bookstore from a garage in Seattle.

Today, Bezos's brainchild is the second most valuable company in the world, worth US$928 billion, and is described as "the most powerful brand" on Earth.

Amazon's reach and growth seems limitless.

But as Bezos said to his employees recently: "Amazon is not too big to fail. In fact, I predict one day Amazon will fail. If you look at large companies, their lifespans tend to be 30-plus years, not a hundred-plus years."

Bezos may be right. As the company looks to the next step in its seeming bid for world domination, it will still need to face down challenges from both consumer and regulatory headwinds.

Amazon's activities in the retail sector are perhaps the most recognized, and the most criticized. However, in a letter to shareholders in April, Bezos even said that Amazon was still "a small player in global retail".

Retail sales at Amazon have risen from US$51 billion to US$59.7 billion in the first quarter of 2019. However, growth has slowed dramatically. In North America, revenues increased 17 per cent compared to 46 per cent in 2018, with international growth dropping to nine per cent from 34 per cent.

But there are problems brewing. A U.S. federal court ruling last week that Amazon can be held liable for a dog collar sold on its website that partly blinded a woman could complicate the online merchant's business if it is applied broadly.

More than half the items sold on the popular site come from independent merchants. Amazon takes a commission on sales and charges additional fees for storing products in its warehouses, packaging them and delivering them.

But it technically doesn't own the inventory, a fact it has used to protect itself from product liability cases. A report by a consumer group called Which? found that unscrupulous sellers are beating Amazon's security systems with tactics such as bribery and hacking to post fake reviews for their products.

The watchdog said features designed to make the online giant's website more user-friendly were being "abused on a grand scale" to mislead customers.

These challenges haven't stopped Bezos from innovating and making aggressive acquisitions such as the US$13.7-billion purchase of Whole Foods in 2017 - but whether his approach will pay off remains to be seen.

"There are two types of retailers in the world today. Those which will be replaced by Amazon, and those which won't," says Ivan Mazour, chief executive and founder of AI-powered customer marketing platform Ometria. "Amazon's all-encompassing vision will provide us with all of our 'needs'. But our 'wants'will continue to be satisfied by innovative 'direct to consumer' brands."

While Amazon certainly will have its eyes on the future of retail, its cloud computing platform Amazon Web Services (AWS) is now its most profitable business. Launched in 2002, AWS has quietly established itself as one of the most prominent technology platforms in the world and is on track to earn US$31 billion in revenue this year.

Essentially selling cloud computing and storage as a service, AWS is used by 5,000 government organizations worldwide, institutions such as NASA and huge companies like Uber and Netflix.

A report by consumer group called Which? found that unscrupulous sellers are beating Amazon's security systems with tactics such as bribery and hacking to post fake reviews for their products.

The company also continues to face scrutiny over work conditions in warehouses and the company's tax contributions.

The U.S. government is gearing up for a major probe into big tech, which could lead to a significant breakup and one that Amazon will be looking to prepare for.
