FINANCIAL TIMES BIRD SOARS AS INVESTORS BET ON SCOOTER-SHARING Electric scooter sharing start-up Bird Rides is talking to investors about raising another funding round of as much as $200m (£149m), even as the ink is still drying on its latest $150m deal, according to people familiar with the discussions. At the same time, Bird could see its valuation nearly double to $1.5bn, these people said. The rapid pace of Bird's fundraising suggests that some in Silicon Valley are convinced it will be more than a fad.

GLENCORE WRITES OFF $5.6BN TO END DISPUTE Glencore yesterday said it has agreed to write off $5.6bn (£4.1bn) of debt in a debt-for-equity swap to safeguard a joint venture in the Democratic Republic of Congo, which is set to become the world's biggest producer of cobalt, a battery material.

THE TIMES POLICE WATCHDOG: TECH FIRMS MUST UP CRIME FIGHT Tech companies face "ever tightening" state regulation after failing to do enough to stop terrorists, paedophiles and organised criminals exploiting their services, the police watchdog has warned. Sir Tom Winsor accused the big tech firms of continuing to devise ways to frustrate law enforcement that he said would rebound on them.

NETFLIX BAN ON MORE THAN FIVE-SECOND EYE CONTACT Films crews working on Netflix shows have been told not to look at each other for longer than five seconds in a crackdown on inappropriate conduct, it has been claimed.

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH PETROPAVLOVSK BOSS QUIT AFTER MINUTES CHANGE The former boss of gold miner Petropavlovsk quit because company directors - including Chelsea Football Club chairman Bruce Buck - altered the minutes of a board meeting to remove extensive discussion of a refinancing deal and failed to act on its urgency.

MACEDONIA CHANGES NAME TO END GREECE DISPUTE Greece and Macedonia reached an historic agreement yesterday to end a bitter 27-year name dispute that had kept the smaller and younger country out of international institutions such as Nato and the EU, the two countries' prime ministers announced.

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ZTE SHARES SET TO RESUME TRADING FOLLOWING DEAL Shares of ZTE are set to resume trading today following a nearly two-month suspension, after a fresh deal with US authorities to keep the Chinese telecom giant in business. ZTE said it filed paperwork with the Hong Kong stock exchange to resume trading in its shares there starting at 9am today.

FACEBOOK TO BAN SELLERS OF SHODDY PRODUCTS Facebook said it will crack down on e-commerce businesses that flood users' feeds with ads for products that are unsatisfactory or don't arrive on time in a new feature that lets people leave feedback about their experience.

FINANCIAL TIMES SKECHERS TRIPPED UP BY SOFT GUIDANCE Skechers shares came undone last night, after the footwear maker issued underwhelming guidance for the current quarter. The California-based company said that it is looking for sales between $1.12bn (£795m) and $1.145bn in the current quarter, and diluted earnings per share between 38 cents and 43 cents. Analysts on average had been looking for sales of about $1.15bn and earnings of 55 cents a share, according to Factset data.

LAGARDE URGES GREATER SCRUTINY OF BIG TECH IMF boss Christine Lagarde has called for politicians to step up scrutiny of the market power of technology companies such as Amazon and Google, warning that they threatened innovation and productivity gains. "It requires new thinking, for sure, and quickly," she said.

THE TIMES QUEEN BACKS CHARLES FOR COMMONWEALTH ROLE The Queen removed any remaining doubts over whether the Prince of Wales would succeed her as head of the Commonwealth when she gave him her explicit backing at the formal opening of the Commonwealth summit at Buckingham Palace yesterday.

UNION BOSS ATTACKS AMBER RUDD OVER WINDRUSH Amber Rudd's criticism of Home Office staff over the Windrush debacle is an attempt to deflect attention from immigration policies from the last eight years, the head of the top civil servants' union said. His claim was backed by former deputy PM Nick Clegg.

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH COMPARE THE MARKET GIVES RESTAURANT HELPING HAND Comparison giant Compare The Market is set to plough millions of pounds into a dining out scheme entitling its customers to cut-price meals at thousands of restaurants. It said its deal with Tastecard would mean anyone buying a product or switching provider would be entitled to 2-for-1 on food for 12 months.

CAMERON:WEST NEEDS TO 'REDISCOVER ITS MOJO' Former UK Prime Minister David Cameron has said the West should "rediscover its democratic mojo" and called for "a bit of a fightback" against populism.

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL PHILIP MORRIS STOCK SEES WORST DAY IN A DECADE Shares of tobacco companies tumbled after Philip Morris International said cigarette shipments fell more than expected and sales for its cigarette alternative started to stall in a key market - raising wider alarm about the health of the entire tobacco industry.

WELLS FARGO CLOSE TO $1BN SETTLEMENT Financial service company Wells Fargo is close to settling claims by federal regulators related to its risk management, involving a fine of as much as $1bn (£710m), sources said. The settlement is expected to be announced as soon as today.
